turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Any man who wants a passport and he wants to engage in governmental work or be relieved of the personal sanctions can get out of the organization.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: He can -- he can get out of the organization.
Now, if you --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) dealing with those people who were -- who were in and who were subject to the sanctions of the Act, I think when we -- when we determine what the legal effect to this Act is and we can't say, "Well, it's a very easy answer, just get out."

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, if the organization is the character of organization that has been -- it has been found to be, what right have they to remain in?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, that's a questions we'd determine whether -- whether they have the right --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: What -- what --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to do it in that way.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: What right, what real right is being destroyed?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As a member of this organization that -- that this man as a member of this organization, can he be denied a passport here because the organization has been, I'll use the term, outlawed?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: If the organization has been outlawed or found to answer this description and he persists in being a member --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he says, "Oh, I'm one of these -- the world is full of very nice innocent people (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: They say I don't believe this.
Can he test it and say, "You hold up denying me a passport until I can prove to you that it isn't so because I wasn't before the Board when this determination was made --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and you are now making -- you're now depriving me of the right to see my mother and Emilio in France and where not, although I contest the conclusion."

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Would Your Honor think that it -- it's reasonable to require that in each application for a passport, if a man has shown to be a member of the Communist Party they've got to go all over again proving -- proving the nature of the Communist Party?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And then -- then I misunderstood you much earlier and a man who has been working in a defense plan, he can be tried without going to --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: If he is listed as a member --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- and persistent in remaining in as a member, he's given time to get out.
He's given a locus poenitentiae under the statute.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But he says I've got a very good lawyer perhaps as skilled as though through a defendant or I've got a lawyer who got a different strategy, a lawyer --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- bearing that strategy.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And maybe they wanted to be outlawed, that suggestion has been made, they like to be modeled by the business, illegitimate rather than legitimate.
I'm not --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- suggesting that, it's my belief, but I have heard talk like that.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It is nice you reminded on (Inaudible) says I got a lawyer who can prove that it isn't so.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, men have often have been seriously damaged because they guessed wrong on their lawyers.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That's up to him.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, General, in this case, the passport is not only denied to such a person but it's made a criminal offense for him to apply for one, isn't it?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That's right -- that's right as long as he's a member of the organization.
He can get out.
The organization can purge itself then could change its character.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As much as -- making a decision in this case must have passed (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: You don't have to pass on any of these questions, all that this statute -- all that this case brings before you is the validity of the registration features.
You're not required by this record to go into all the possible cases that may arise of individuals or front organizations.
Many considerations that apply here may not apply to organizations of a different character.
Well, the -- the relationship to this conspiracy is -- is tenuous where there's a possibility that people who belonged who didn't know the nature of the movement.
You don't have that here, you have the Communist Party, this is it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: As with many questions (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I don't know, they -- they say that they're the only ones, that they claim an exemption because they're preeminent in this -- in this movement.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: No, but there are good many (Inaudible) who are hardly convinced about that and of pure of heart, aren't they?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: All right.
Well, if you have people that are pure of heart who are brought here and you feel that they are being violated, you'll protect them.

But here's an organization, they're no individuals, the organization that is designed -- I forgot in which opinion I read this, one of the opinions of this Court, designed not as a political party but design as a part a conspiracy to further a foreign conspiracy.
If you have that kind of an organization, pass on that case and don't -- let's try in this case, on this record to adjudicate cases that may arise in the future under an entirely different facts.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could Congress on the basis of this commission's -- of this Board's findings then pass a legislation abolishing the Communist Party?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Congress has tried to do that in the 1954 Act --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- effectively to abolish them because they -- they outlaw them, they take away all their rights.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: That was without a determination by anybody except the congressional?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: A congressional determination.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What I am suggesting --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I'm not -- I'm not here defending that today.
I mean --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What I'm -- what I'm asking you is this, supposing the statute had provided that -- that the findings that have been made in the preambles here and then a board has been created to make a determination of fact unnoticed to the Communist Party and so forth.
And then the Board had made the determination that it has on adequate evidence if you please but Congress then followed that up and say, "Now, we'll abolishing the -- the Communist Party."

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That -- that particular part I don't know why not, they've had -- they've had full opportunity to be heard and it's determined that they are conspirators.
I don't know what exemptions they are entitled to.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, I'm -- I'm not --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I mean --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- suggesting they couldn't, I was asking should --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, I say I don't know, I haven't thought of that, about that because that's not this case but that goes much further than -- than this statute goes.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No, but that's the nub of what your opponent say as the result of this (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, but it -- it isn't -- it just isn't so.
You're not -- I say with great respect, you're not to pass on questions that aren't before you, they haven't arisen.
You may see to think an entirely different life if it's presented by (a) who is on a certain situation and from what you'd say if it's presented by (b) an entirely different situation.
One may have knowledge.
The other may not have knowledge.
Here you're not -- you're not dealing with that kind of a situation.
This is not some -- some person who is being condemned out of his hearing.

This is not a case where like in -- in the Bailey case which is mentioned here this morning whether -- neither the organization nor the individual was given any hearing, any proper hearing and the opinion of -- of some people.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But -- well, you -- you say really we've just got two questions before us.

One is whether the act of registration, the act requiring registration is within congressional competence and number two whether the findings of the Board were adequate so if they should (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Just those two questions (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That -- that's all -- that's all.
I think if you look over the -- this criteria that they speak of, the inferences that were drawn, the definition is in this Section 3 that was right here.
The 13 (e) are merely a list of things that Congress says the Board may consider.
It doesn't substitute them for the definition.

I think the evidence is -- is ample and if you harbor any doubts as to the validity of some parts of the statute or its possible application in cases in the future, that in determining the constitutionality of an Act of Congress is no reason for striking the Act down.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And you say you don't need a jury to determine whether or not they should raise it?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I don't think so, you don't -- there -- there are many, many things that may be determined without a jury.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: In a criminal case it would be a different thing.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: A different thing and the punishments here are not criminal, I take it.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: It's just this labeling --

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: So you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- and registration.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- you do have disadvantages to this organization by -- by registration?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Oh, yes, this wasn't done to make the Communist Party comfortable.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And this -- this question whether you can make the money profitable as you press it in this way or as a matter of due process.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: They -- I think they have had ample due process.
I think they have had a very careful and conscientious examination.

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) due process but have --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: -- and they had (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I think they have had both.
I think they have had both and they can always -- if they really want to change their character, the statute gives them an open door (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That isn't all that -- that isn't all that happened -- that isn't all that happened because the determination, the incomparable determination against them as a -- as a body or the collectivity --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- then operate in the case that the Chief Justice put to you.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, but they have a perfect right -- they have a perfect right --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: To get out --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- to move very quickly.
No, but the Party itself if it is an innocent Boy Scout movement, it can --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not talking --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- it can convert itself to that.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I'm not talking about the Party.
I'm talking about a real innocent Boy Scout --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- who believes in the kingdom of heaven on earth --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- it's through that.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There are such people.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: If you have such a person -- if you have such a person, you will find him not guilty if -- if he's accused.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, it's substantially foreclosed by the fact that the Communist Party is what the Board has found and the Court has confirmed --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: But --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and then he told, he's out of a plant job, he's out of employment, he can't go abroad and live his life elsewhere and all the other country.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Mr. Justice, if a man is working in the defense plant and he's told, "You're a member of the Communist Party, it has been adjudicated a conspiracy."
And he says, "I insist however on belonging to it."

turn.speaker: stanley_reed
turn.label: Justice Stanley Reed
turn.text: And those are consequences and not penalties, is that (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: They're consequences he -- he brings on himself, he insists on it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That will give them much comfort if we call them consequences and not penalty.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Even though --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Even penalties, let's call them penalties.
Let's even call them penalties --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: It's something that he doesn't have to suffer.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you don't even let him get out of the country.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: When he gets out of a party, he can get out of country and if -- if they -- if they still withhold the -- the passport from him, he can go to court and there have been --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- cases of that sort.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- a party is -- there is what it's found to be, but you don't want to keep members of it here who want to leave the country, just to be a little --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the reason that I -- doesn't mean on all the (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: All right.
I -- I'm not here to defend every Act of Congress as wise and I don't think I have to lecture that subject to this Court or -- or to the member who is addressing this question to me.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That wouldn't be a fair burden to put on to you?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: No.
[Laughter]
I don't -- I don't think it's a necessary -- a necessary test.
Now, the Douds case is authority for the proposition that Congress may say to a man, "If you want to be an officer of a union, you've got to resign from the Communist Party."
The Douds case decided that.
Now, if you can say to a man, "You can't be an officer of a union if you're a member of the Communist Party."

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That isn't quite like the Douds case, certainly you can't be an officer of a union that wants to evade itself to the facility of the Labor Board.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: If they want to keep you as an officer of the Board, it's not a union's (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Then they are stripped of their -- of certain rights.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, they are stripped of certain rights just as this Party here in -- in this case.

So after all, this is no child's play, the -- the Congress has a right to -- to put some teeth in this law but it isn't an irrational, it isn't a savage thing to do and if you give them a full opportunity to be heard and you determined the nature of the organization and you give them an opportunity periodically, if they really sincerely can show that they have changed, they can -- they can be relieved of the consequences.
If on the other hand, they persist then they can't say were -- we're being denied rights.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: General, there's one other thing that -- that concerned me when -- when you cite the Lobbyist Act and --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- and other Acts of that character as being analogous to -- to this one.
In those Acts, as I remember, the -- they were really registration acts and if they complied with the law and registered, there were no sanctions.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: But in this case, the mere registration imposes the sanctions.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That's true.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And there -- that -- that makes the distinction now, what the --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: But in -- in this --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: The fact is, I don't know --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- but I'd like --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: No, but it -- there's this difference.
In the case of the lobbyist, all in -- he is doing is disclosing his activities, it's not inherently an unlawful activity.
Here, these people have been shown to be engaged in unlawful activity and I think that -- that makes a big difference.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but a question was raised as whether -- whether he has a right to show that on his trial or whether he has to rely on the finding of some -- some board --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, he can show --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- to that effect.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: If -- if on his trial, he is one -- that he can show or convince the -- the Court, the jury that he's one of those innocents that Mr. Justice Frankfurter spoke of, I suppose there would be a verdict of not guilty.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, would that be available to him?
As I understood it -- I understood you a little awhile ago, you said if the Board had determined that the organization he belonged to was illegal --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that was conclusive upon him and that when he was prosecuted for -- for not registering, it wasn't opened to him just to say, "Well, this -- this wasn't a --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- that kind of an organization, so consequently I am not guilty."

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That he can't say.
He can't say that the -- that I'm going to re-litigate the character of the organization.
But if his lawyers can convince the jury that he is really an innocent, that he did not understand the character of the organization then he would be found not guilty.
That much would be open to him, not the character of the organization but the character of his connection with the organization.
I think --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In connection with your lobbying example there --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- suppose Congress says it's a crime not to register as a lobbyist and then it turned over to an agency such as this one, the power to determine first whether the man was actually engaged in lobbying and then you came up and said he -- he was tried.

You submitted to the jury the question not whether he was engaged in lobbying because that could have been decided by the Board, but you submitted to the jury the question whether he had failed to register.
Could you do that?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Whether he had failed to register.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right.
You make it a crime for a lobbyist to fail to register and then permit determination of the facts of whether he is a lobbyist to be decided by a board --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, now --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- and give them -- throw him before the jury with the sole defense of whether he failed to register.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: No, but you've got -- you've got a double thing here.
You've got not merely his failure, you've got the problem of the character of the organization.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: All right, take -- let's take for instance the -- the example the Chief gave you.
I think mine is pretty close to lobbyist but let's take the other one, it's probably a little closer.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: An organization of people engaged in the cattle business in western Utah and you appoint a board and they find that while they're -- they're all engaged in the cattle business and they have an association.

But the Board at the hearing determines that they are -- the organization has been engaged in stealing cattle and then you try a man for failing to -- you tried him for failing to register and you impose a sanction on everybody that belongs to it or belonging to it and say they can't get a passport.
They can't get a job at certain places.
You think Congress could do that?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, but, Your Honor, the assumption here is that there is really a legitimate work that they are doing, cattle raising.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I would suppose --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Suppose it were -- may I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I understand of course if you say that there's no possibility of this particular group doing anything illegal --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- or you did say that they might say that they were for unemployment insurance and things like that.

But here, you have an organization that the Chief asked you, are you going to permit a board to determine whether a certain group, association or such nature that the mere fact that a man belongs to it without letting him -- letting them try those facts to the court jury, subject him to sanctions under the law imposed by the Federal Government all over the -- sanctions from everybody all over the United States.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: It depends on the nature of the activity.
This is not merely a business that can have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But it depends on who decides the nature of the activity if you are going to penalize them, by the Board, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Congress has prescribed what is the -- what is the -- one of the characteristics of the activity that it wants to forbid.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, suppose Congress would just say, "You just (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: And it comes down --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- by a jury at all."
Could they do that?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: No, they couldn't do that.
They couldn't do that, but I don't know of anything in the Constitution that says that a thing of this sort cannot be determined by a board.
The OPA, example, is -- is one example and draft boards frequently determine --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- whether --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: There Congress gave a board the right to -- in effect delegated the power to fix a general price applicable to everybody alike.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, everybody alike -- unfortunately, there aren't many Communist Parties.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But -- well, the importance of today is the Communist Party.
I understand that fully from what you've said and what I've read, but the -- the language does not limit thereby to them.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes, but it limits them to a foreign -- an organization dominated by a foreign power and owing allegiance to them and furthering their work.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But suppose they do --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Well, they do --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Let's -- let's take suppose they do --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose that's right.
Do you think by that, that that gives Congress any more right?
You -- you bring that up each time.
You think that gives them any more right if they have done it, to deprive them of a trial by jury than it would you?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Trial by a jury of any individual --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes, yes --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: -- is -- is still here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: A trial by -- do you think that -- that gives Congress the mere fact that they are (Inaudible) and we don't -- we're not like and they are dangerous, the right to have them tried without the benefits of a trial by a jury where they tried to attack.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: In -- in this -- in this law, all that is determined by the Board is the nature of the Communist Party.
So far as individuals are concerned, they have the right of a trial by a jury on all other issues.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's right, but that is foreclosed when they get there because a board has passed on it.

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: That one issue is foreclosed.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But then -- and you of course wouldn't say that that was justified because they're Communists rather than -- than --

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: Not because -- not because they are Communists but because they are conspirators against the Government.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, would you say that -- would you say that if they are conspirators against the Government and you could prove it before a jury that you can assume that and therefore try them before a board?

turn.speaker: simon_sobeloff
turn.label: Mr. Simon E. Sobeloff
turn.text: I don't see how you could re-litigate this question as a practical matter in -- in the case of each individual.

You've got to -- there -- there are many instances in the law where you have a representative action and the issue is litigated fully and other people are bound by what they -- what is there to determine as to that issue.

turn.speaker: joseph_forer
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Forer
turn.text: I think I have about two minutes, Chief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: joseph_forer
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Forer
turn.text: As I understand the Solicitor General, he now in substance concedes that a registration order against an accused organization for all practical purposes will destroy it or cripple it, proscribe it, outlaw it, put it out of business, call it what you will.
Nevertheless, he says this is not a First Amendment case.

He says nobody has a constitutional right to engage in a conspiracy to overthrow the Government, of course that's true and I put aside for the moment the question that there was no proof of such a conspiracy in this case.
Let's assume there was proof.
Let's assume it was proved that the Communist Party is a conspiracy to overthrow the Government of the United States.

You can punish that conspiracy, if the Court please, but you can't prohibit a conspirator and this is the Chief Justice's illustration if I understood it, you can't prohibit that conspirator from engaging in legitimate peaceful advocacy.
Solicitor General says but none of their advocacy is legitimate or peaceful because it's all for a bad motive.
When they say we're against race discrimination, when they say we're for higher wages, when they say we're for peace, they are really doing this as part of a conspiracy to overthrow the Government.
I submit, if the Court please, that one of the oldest devices of intolerance was -- is to say, "Yes, you're doing a good thing but we're punishing you because they do it for a bad purpose."

As soon as the Government has the power to punish a legitimate activity because it labels that activity as being done for a bad purpose, you've armed a government with the power to suppress all legitimate activity.
